Posts.Title: How Many Are We? zarovka SimonH

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2014 09:10AM DianneNC wrote: First diagnosed at 44, mets now at 47. Mammograms every year since I was 20, the year my 31 year old sister died of BC. Also have another sister who was diagnosed when she was 38, but is a 22 year survivor and still going strong. We are BRCA - but I am meeting with the genetic team again this week. Apparently, there is a new gene identified they want to test me for. I certainly hope there is something that will spare my daughter from this road! Mammogram never showed my tumor, but with my family history they took the palpable lump seriously from the start and it showed up on the MRI. We treated my first diagnosis very aggressively, and I intend to fight this new diagnosis with all I have. I'm not a big believer in "catching it early" at this point. I've been diligent for 27 years, found my tumor myself, and still have mets. Enough with the "awareness" campaign, and let's find a cure!!!!
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2015 09:24AM DianneNC wrote: Great topic, and one I have wrestled with as well. I have a question regarding the short/long term disability and the social security disability. Can you collect both at the same time? Does one off set the other? I know my short term pays 50% of my salary, which will be very difficult for my family. If I could pair the two together, it may be manageable. Anyone know how this works?
Posts.Title: Financial and Career Implications of Cancer LynnFish Lumpie

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 09:30PM - edited Apr 12, 2012 09:31PM by DianneNC I've been lingering on these boards since diagnosis, so I guess it's time to jump in. I start my T/C on April 23rd, so I'm anxiously reading every morsel I can get my hands on. Thank you all so much for sharing your journey! I had BMX with DIEP reconstruction on March 12, with some major, unfortunate complications. So now, I have a BMX and will likely go the TE/implant route following chemo. One of my incisions is not healed 100%, which is why I have to wait a little longer for chemo to begin. I certainly don't want to do chemo, but the waiting is making me crazy! I hate any of us have to be here, but it sure is nice to know we aren't alone!

Posts.Content: May 8, 2012 04:22PM DianneNC wrote: Hiker, I used clippers. Actually, my son did! :) My daughter cut my ponytail off, then just chopped my hair all over super short. Then my son took over with the clippers using a .5 guard. That is closest guard without just going to the skin. I was worried about razor burn, which is why he used the guard. We actually made sort of a fun party out of it...much better that way for us. They both wanted to shave theirs (along with my husband) but I talked them out of it. I said I could avoid mirrors if I wanted to, but I couldn't ignore it if we were ALL bald. Thanks for the support and all, but I prefer they stay just the way they are! Myleftboob, glad to hear this part of your treatment is in your rear view mirror!!! Hope the next phase is an easy one!!

Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: May 19, 2012 05:31PM DianneNC wrote: Hi everyone, I've been MIA all week just exhausted! I had tx2 on Monday and actually had a pretty good week with side effects. Knock on wood....hope I didn't jinx myself by putting that out there!!! I was really tired, but otherwise felt pretty good. So far I have even managed to not get the dreaded rash!!! I really, really suffered with the rash the first treatment so I have been living in dread each day waiting for it to show up. So far, so good and no sign of it. By this time last treatment I was in agony with the rash and terrible diarrhea, but I actually had a really good day today. Went for a three mile walk in this beautiful weather, then did some shopping with my daughter. My doctor told me to use Benadryl cream on the rash, and it did help some, for those of you struggling with it right now. This is what I did differently this time, if it will help anyone: I started taking Prilosec 5 days before treatment, and continued for 5 days after. This helped with the acidy tummy and belching issues. I took 2 senna tablets the day before, day of and day after treatment to ward off the constipation. Worked like a charm, and so far no D train either!! Good grief, I hope this keeps up!! Took Claratin day of and 2 days after Neulasta shot. I'll try all these things again in 2 weeks for the next one and I sure hope I get off as easy again. Melrose, I admire that you still have some hair. I was so afraid of looking like a patchy burn victim, I just went for it. I have worn my wig twice going out to dinner, but otherwise I just wear a hat. When I finally go back to work, I know I will wear it all the time so I am just enjoying the break while I can. I'm sure it will be months and months with the wig after treatment, and I've just gotten used to being bald around the house. I actually go bald when I go for my walks so I can get a little sunshine on my head. :) A lady stopped her car she she saw me the otherday, took off her wig and said "hey, we have the same haircut!" Nice to see a little BC solidarity in the neighborhood!! Take care everyone!!
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2012 01:36AM DianneNC wrote: So I guess all those folks who said the steroids would keep you up all night weren't kidding?!? It's 1:30 here and I have to be up at 6:30 to head off to my first chemo tomorrow. Hmmmm, maybe this means I'll sleep through the infusion and all the fun that wil entail tomorrow! I'm hoping I fall asleep eventually, but I'm wide awake. Drat.
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2012 12:42PM DianneNC wrote: Prilosec was my savior earlier this week, too. Every time I belched it made me feel nauseous, so I knew I had to do something. My main discomfort yesterday was major constipation and yucky feeling mouth. I found drinking watered down lemonade made my mouth feel a little better. I usually don't care for lemonade (too acidic) but watering down raspberry lemonade has been heaven the past day or two. Now I need to find a food that tastes ok. So far the only thing that tastes good is chocolate...not good! :) now I'm going to try some more Miralax and try to get things moving. I hate to treat it too aggressively since I hear diarreah will be coming next...ugh! My MO is only doing blood work on me right before treatment, so I have no idea what my levels are. I'm going to go with "no news is good news" and assume everything is just fine. How's that for blind optimism! :)
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2012 12:28PM DianneNC wrote: Just checking with everyone. It's been a long week, but certainly doable like everyone says. I have found that I have a different side effect each day. If they all hit at once I don't know how I could stand it, but literally every day is something new. Yesterday was a horrible skin rash all over my chest and neck. Actually it is more like a burn with baby blisters! It is bright red and itches something awful. I kept myself konked out on Benadryl most of the day to keep from scratching my skin off!!! It is better today-- just very red and some of the "blisters" feel dried out. it is irritating today, but not unbearable like yesterday. So, I wonder what new side effect will show itself today?!? Slak, the constipation has gone after 2 days of Miralax and hopefully I'll escape the rest of the yuckies like you. :)
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: May 3, 2012 06:47PM DianneNC wrote: Hi there to all the new comers! I'm at day 10 after treatment one, and almost feel normal. Not bad!! My "gastro-intestinal" issues were the yucky, but I survived it, and things are much better now. My hair is still holding on, but it looks terrible. Everyone says to cut your hair super short before treatment, and I ignored that advice. I wanted to look like me as long as I could. Now I kind of look like me with really damaged hair. :) It is very dry and flat, but no sense in paying for a haircut when I suspect it will all be gone within a week or so. Melrose, I think you started the day after me, so I like to check in to see how your doing! I have been so worried about gaining weight on chemo, but that hasn't stopped me for eating junk. I had Doritos for lunch today...so heathly!! I'm hoping to go for a walk tomorrow since I'm feeling better, but it has been 90 degrees in NC this week, and the heat takes it out of me. I go back and forth between taking it easy on myself with all I have going on, and being a slacker because I have an excuse!!
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 09:25AM DianneNC wrote: Stay shiny, I lost quite a bit of weight last year too...65 pounds actually. I am convinced I would not have found the lump if not for the weight loss, and the recovery from my surgery was certainly easier with all that weight gone! I lost 10 pounds with my surgery, but gained about 5 of that back. For now, my weight is stable. I lost a little last week since I didn't really eat anything, gained it back now that I am feeling better. I am very concerned about gaining weight on chemo, but I'm also trying not to stress out about it. I keep reminding myself to just focus on being healthy and taking care of myself. Obviously, I needed a little more "reminding" the other day when I had Doritos for lunch!! :) I had a salad for lunch yesterday, so there is hope for me yet!! Back to hair, my head is starting to get a little itchy so maybe the time is near. I heard the hair on the arms and legs would go first, but that is still holding on strong, too. The waiting is the worst! This is what I get for not listening to the wise folks who ALL said to cut my hair short!!!

We'll see if I'm brave enough to just do it!

Posts.Content: May 5, 2012 03:18PM DianneNC wrote: Thanks everyone! I've said from the start that I would shave it at the first sign of loss. We plan on making it a family event...my daughter is cutting off the pony tail and then my son is using the clippers. I think I will have him do it with the shortest guard, but not all the way to the scalp. He's in college, and he and all his roommates shave each other's hair. Cheaper than a barber, and now he's experienced! :) He's coming home for dinner tomorrow, so I will just skip the hair washing tomorrow morning and hope the rest lasts until dinner tomorrow! Diane- I loved your grandson's comment about the clown! And I'm envious of the Panama City trip!! I am a sun lover and my MO told me to just be super vigilant about sunscreen. The chemo does make us much more sensitive to the sun.
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: May 8, 2012 01:06PM - edited May 8, 2012 01:06PM by DianneNC Hi hair buddies! I did shave it Saturday night. It wasn't fun, but honestly I'm glad it's over. I knew I was going to lose it all, and the waiting game was more stresful for me personally. I've been wearing hats, but I do go for a walk every morning bald so my head can get a little sunshine. I think it will look a little better if it isn't so bright white! Hiker, sorry to hear about the digestive issues. It was rough for me for about 6 days, and then I had another 6 days of diarrhea. Miserable....both ways! I am enjoying this week of "normalcy" knowing that it is all starting over again next Monday. I am going to take the probiotic advice and see if it helps. Hope things get "moving" for you soon! :)
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: May 14, 2012 12:51PM DianneNC wrote: Looks like I missed a bunch of posts over the weekend. We went touring some Virginia wineries for the Mother's Day weekend. What an awesome way to spend a weekend before treatment!! :) I am in the infusion chair right now getting #2 of 4. So far, no issues. It interesting to see how some of us get 4 and some 6. My surgerical onc told me to expect 6 treatments, but the MO was comfortable recommending 4. I'm stage 2a grade 3 ER, PR +, HER 2-, and my onco was 19. A big factor for me is having 2 sisters who were diagnosed in their 30's. I'm 44, but it's a pretty scary family history. Especially having ILC that does not show on a mammogram at all....I was ready to throw anything they have to make sure I only have to do this once! I'll have to check my path report when I get home, because the Ki67 doesn't ring a bell. Probably because I had no clue what it is I just skimmed over that part! Here's to hoping for minimal side effect for all this week!! Oh, and Melrose-- welcome to club baldy! I totally agree with you that the hair falling out was much worse that just getting it over with. Frankly, it's bad enough that I have hair from my cat shedding all over the house...I didn't want another mess to clean! I have been wearing hats most of the time, but I do have a couple wigs. I got an awesome one at the cancer center last week that looks so much like my own hair, only better!! Much more volume and it's always styled and pretty looking....not like my real hair! :) I save the wig for when I got out, but I just keep a cotton cap on my head at home.
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2012 07:08PM DianneNC wrote: Oh, Hiker so sorry to hear you about such horrible side effects!! I hope there is something they can do to give you some relief and map out a SAFE plan for the next steps. Hugs to you, my friend!
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2012 01:37PM DianneNC wrote: Hello all, I had my first treatment Monday and so far so good. I just kind of have that yucky hungover feeling, but nothing too awful yet. Fingers crossed that it stays this way. I know it probably won't, but I can dream! I am very tired today, just sort of napping off and on. I gave myself the Neulasta shot last night at 7, and had taken a Claratin at 3. I felt some pain come and go with that, but again it was manageable. What is not manageable is the cost of the shots! I had them shipped to my home so I would not have to drive an hour each way to the hospital. Biometrics called me last week and said they would ship the shots in a cold pack and my co-pay is $100. Imagine my panic when I finally opened the actual package last night and saw only ONE shot included. I thought there was a mistake or somehow I threw ay the other three shots with the massive packaging they included. Seriously, the box is a one foot cube with ONE little vial of medicine in it! Apparently, they will ship them one at a time the week before my treatment and they are $100 EACH. That was a surprise I could have done without. I just have to remind myself that I am blessed to have this life saving treatment available to me, and the $400 certainly will not spiral me into financial ruin. Just another unexpected bump in the road. Let me go back to being grateful for feeling not so bad today! :) Be well everyone!
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 03:53PM DianneNC wrote: I'm with you, Melorose on the chapped lips. I even had a really nasty blister similar to what covered the rest of my body over the past week. Miserable. I'm trying the Eucerin today!! Totally UNFAIR about not losing the leg hair. I have to shave EVERY DAY, and this was the only part of chemo I was looking forward to!!!! My plastic surgeon offered to give me free laser hair removal anywhere i wanted, but turns out I'm not a candidate because my hair is too light. I can't catch a break!! :)
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: May 9, 2012 07:12AM DianneNC wrote: Thinking of you today, Stayshiney. Hope you have an uneventful infusion and a wonderful picnic!!! I hear you on the sunshine. I heard the cancer center at Duke actually has outdoor infusion chairs...how cool would that be?!?
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: May 21, 2012 10:32AM DianneNC wrote: Hey Shiny, I've had to do some shopping, but trying not to do too much. I had a failed DIEP surgery in March, so now I have a nice flat tummy but unfortunately I have a flat chest to match it. I've bought a bunch of tops to camouflage my chest becase I haven't gotten prosthetics or anything, but I don't want to buy clothes because I have no idea how I will end up. I just rock my bald head and flat chest and remind myself that this shall pass. I spend my time shopping for the vacation we will take when all this is done! We decided to take a cruise over New Years to St. Martin and St. Thomas. What better way to ring in 2013 at sea and cancer free!!!!!! I'll have to do some serious shopping for that trip!!
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: May 24, 2012 09:46AM DianneNC wrote: Like- so sorry to hear the tough emotional road you've been on, and I'm glad you found a counselor to help. All that would suck when you're feeling100%, can't imagine how hard it is in the middle of chemo! Very glad to hear you finished your last treatment and now it's all improvement from here. Summer- I'm encouraged that you were able to go to the beach with no problem. We are heading there tomorrow, and I've been worried about the sun. I confess I love nothing more than laying on the beach for hours lost in a book. The ocean really is soul restoring for me, and I'm optimistic that if I go crazy with sunscreen I should still be able to enjoy the weekend in the sun. My sister is bringing an umbrella-- this will be the first time in my life sitting under an umbrella on the beach! Melrose- I still have eyebrows and lashes, but my lashes are thinning a little. I have only had to shave my legs twice in the past 3 weeks, and that is usually a daily chore. That has been the only upside to chemo! I was hoping to not have to shave at all, but at least most of it is gone. Oddly, I appear to have all my arm hair. It is white, so it's hard to tell if it's thinner, but it's definitely still there. All in all, things are going well. Treatment 2 was not bad at all, and I'm glad to be heading in to the holiday weekend feeling strong. Looking forward to the beach this weekend, and then we are taking the kids to DC next weekend for my birthday. Two awesome weekends, then off to treatment three the following Monday. Hope everyone is managing side effects and doing as well as we can. Hugs to all!
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2012 09:27PM DianneNC wrote: Wishing everyone minimal side effects!! I had treatment three today and I get the Neulasta shot tomorrow. I almost asked about skipping the shot this time since my numbers have looked so good, but then decided that my numbers probably look so good because of the shot. Ain't broke, don't fix it!! :) I've heard so many people say that treatment three is the worst, so I gotta say I'm a little nervous. I was so lucky on the 2nd one, I almost feel guilty about it. I've kept myself preoccupied with reconstruction plans as a distraction. That's been a full time job, but it has really kept my mind off chemo. Take care everyone!!
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2012 07:21AM DianneNC wrote: Morning all! I head for my last treatment this morning!! This last one was rough....nothing horrible, but it just wiped me out more than I was prepared for. this heat sure doesn't help; they are calling for it to hit 100 degrees here by mid-week. Odd thing about my hair, I had some serious stubble start to grow back in the last two weeks! Encouraged that regrowth is soon in my future, but I did go ahead and shave the stubble. The right side of my head was baby soft bald, and the right had visible growth. I thought the lopsided look was worse, and I'm hoping for uniform regrowth!!! My eyebrows and eye lashes are still here, but very thin, oddly I have every strand of my arm hair left?!? Good luck to all this week! Minimal side effects and closer to the finish line for all of us!
Posts.Title: March/April Chemo T/C x 4 Catherine22 Summer51
